item.title: Getting Supplies
item.description:
Where do I get my supplies? If this were six or more years ago I'd head down to Pearl Paint on Canal Street just a stones throw from Sum Dum Goy's Fortune Cookie Factory.

Alas that magical store is long gone so what to do?

It seems that most of the instructional videos I find on YouTube have links to supplies but they're all to Amazon and, all things being equal, I'd just as soon give someone else my business. On the other hand, I'm not in a financial place that I want to pay a huge premium out of principal.

Fortunately, I've found two great supplies.

Jerry's Artorama and Blick.

Both have huge inventories, mostly overlapping but not quite the same. Both also seem to have an eternal sale going on. Navigation of both sites takes getting used to but they both operate the same.

Both seem to have very competitive prices.

Jerry's has free shipping on orders over $45 and I generally get my stuff in a couple of days. Blick seems to take longer and while there frequently seems to be a free shipping discount code for orders over $45 I don't know if it's always there.

On the other hand, I get a teacher's discount at Blick and there are multiple brick and mortar Blick stores near my apartment so I can support a local store and get things right away.

I'll also sometimes use Michael's for Canvases but I'll talk about that in the canvas post.

While neither of these are small businesses, both grew out of small local businesses so I'd rather patronize them than Amazon. If I'm missing any other great suppliers, please let me know.

item.title: My Painting Setup
item.description:
Living in Manhattan doesn't allow for a lot of space. I live in a reasonably sized (for Manhattan standards) apartment with my wife and son. My daughter doesn't live with us but she comes down most every day and works out of her old room as a change of pace rather than staying in her apartment and working alone. That leaves us with 4 people sharing space.

There's no room for a real studio as space is at a premium but if you want to paint regularly you don't want to spend 30 minutes doing set up and tear down. I had a french style easel from when I was Bob Ross for Halloween

and it worked well for that with the storage drawer and extending legs but at home, not so much. The telescoping legs that set to a triangle made for a much larger footprint than was necessary. After deciding I was going to stick with this a while, I ended up getting this:

It seems bigger but the footprint is smaller.

I got this branded as a DaVinci easel but there are a bunch out there. I like the shelf on the bottom and I got a couple of hanging baskets to attach to the back to hold paintbrushes which a keep in used tomato cans that I've washed out. :

I throw a cheap plastic tablecloth over the dining table behind the easel and that's where I put my equipment when I work.

I also needed a place to store paintings while they dried. For that I got this rack:

It seems bigger but the footprint is smaller

I got my easel and rack at Jerry's Artorama. I'll write about them in the supplies post. I also got a couple of floor mats and that's pretty much it.

That's it for the setup.

The easel's always out and I try to keep a prepped canvas either on the easel or on my rack so setup is a breeze.

  1. Put the tablecloth over the table

  2. Grab a disposable pallet pad and add paints

  3. Fill my brush cleaning bucket with water (since I'm using water mixable paints) and pull out the trash can / beater rack

and I'm ready to go. Just takes a minute or two.

Cleanup is also pretty quick:

  1. Throw out the paper pallete

  2. Wash the brushes

  3. Remove the tablecloth and throw behind the easel.

Takes about 3 or 4 minutes plus the brush cleaning time.

So that's my setup. Let me know if I should continue this series when I'll talk about my experience with water mixable paints, brushes adn the rest.

item.title: From a small apartment to happy trees
item.description:
Hi fellow painters. Okay, I'm not a painter, I'm a Computer Science teacher in NYC. I thought I'd take up Bob Ross style wet on wet painting and thought that others might benefit from hearing about what I've learned so far in my journey.

Since Covid, like many people I've been spending a lot of time at home and most of my day is facing a computer screen. Work? On screen. Watching TV or videos? On screen. Even reading a book is more often than not, on a screen. I had some painting equipment from around twenty years ago when I went to work as Bob Ross for Halloween but never really painted. I figured now would be a good time to try it for real.

Of course, there were some issues:

  • I live in a NYC Apartment so with my family so space is an issue

  • So are concerns over fumes and hazardous materials - using, storing, and disposing

  • Cost is always an issue

  • Oh, did I mention, in NYC space is always an issue.

In these pages, I'll talk about what I've used, what's worked for me, what I've learned and hopefully others can benefit. I'll start with talking about my setup and how I'm coping with painting in a small apartment. If people find it useful, I'll follow with the other topics that are listed as coming soon.

The stuff

Painting home page

My NYC Apartment Painting setup

Getting Supplies

The paints (water mixable) (coming soon)

Thoughts on canvases (coming soon)

Brushes (coming soon)

Displaying the work (coming soon)

Painting tips?
